node.text:
The FDA appears to have caved to industry pressure and allows intestines potentially infected with mad cow disease prions into food products and lipstick.

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3jHtS2W

node.text:
What is the dirty little secret of drugs for lifestyle diseases? If patients knew the truth of how little these drugs actually worked, almost no one would agree to take them.

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/388EVgu

#HowNotToDie #NutritionFactsOrg #LifestyleMedicine #DailyDozen #DailyDozenChallenge #HowNotToDiet #Plantbased #Plantbaseddiet #Hearthealth #Heartdisease #Longevity #HealthyHeart #Statins #Heartdiseaseprevention #PlantBasedNutrition #PlantBasedEating #WFPBnutrition

node.title: Are Doctors Misleading Patients About Statin Risks and Benefits?

node.text:
What are the effects of açai berries, cooked and raw blueberries, grapes, cocoa, green tea, and freshly squeezed orange juice on artery function?

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3ehkr8F

node.text:
Join us for our next webinar, "Are White Potatoes Bad for You?" on September 17 from 2-3 pm ET. ⁠
⁠
Greater potato consumption is associated with a greater risk of coming down with type 2 diabetes, but of the hundred or so pounds of potatoes Americans eat every year, most are in the deep-fried form of French fries and potato chips. But even baked, boiled, or mashed potatoes seem to carry a small increased risk even after taking all the butter and sour cream into account. The reason that potato consumption may just have a neutral impact on mortality risk (as opposed to other whole plant foods--beans, nuts, vegetables, and fruits--that are linked to a longer life) is that all the fiber and vitamin C and potassium in white potatoes might be counterbalanced by the detrimental effects of their high glycemic index. By chilling and reheating potatoes, and adding vinegar or lemon juice you can dramatically lower the glycemic impact. I’ll also cover the best kinds of potatoes, address concerns about toxic glycoalkaloid compounds in the peel, and answer any questions you may have in this 1-hour live webinar on September 17th.⁠
⁠
Sign-up for the webinar today! September 15th is the last day to register.⁠ https://bit.ly/3sZyOVj⁠
⁠
*Please note, a recording from the webinar will be sent to participants after the live webinar.⁠
⁠
*To access the URL, click the link in our bio and then select this image.⁠

node.text:
ZUCCHINI MEATBALLS
1 (15-ounce) BPA-free can or Tetra Pak salt-free chickpeas, drained, rinsed, and blotted dry
3 garlic cloves, smashed
1/3 cup old-fashioned rolled oats
3 tbsps nutritional yeast
3 tbsps ground flaxseeds
1 tbsp ground chia seeds
2 tsps fresh lemon juice
1 tsp white miso paste
1 ½ tsps dried basil
1 ½ tsps dried oregano
1 tsp onion powder
¼ tsp ground black pepper
1 cup shredded zucchini, squeezed dry

CHIMICHURRI SAUCE
2 ripe Hass avocados, peeled and pitted
2 tbsps fresh lemon juice
1 tbsp red wine vinegar
2-3 garlic cloves, minced
1 tsp white miso paste
½ tsp dried oregano
¼ tsp red pepper flakes, or to taste
¼ tsp ground black pepper
¼ cup chopped fresh cilantro
¼ cup chopped fresh parsley

PASTA
8 ounces whole-grain or bean-based gemelli or other pasta of choice

METHOD:
FOR THE ZUCCHINI MEATBALLS:
Combine the chickpeas, garlic, oats, nutritional yeast, flaxseeds, and chia seeds in a food processor and pulse until finely chopped. Add the lemon juice, miso paste, basil, oregano, onion powder, and black pepper. Pulse until thoroughly mixed. Transfer to a large bowl and add the shredded zucchini. Stir together until well combined. The mixture should hold together when pinched between two fingers. If the mixture is too wet, add a little nutritional yeast or ground flaxseeds to absorb excess moisture.

Preheat the oven to 375°F. Line a baking pan with a silicone mat or parchment paper.
Scoop about 2 tablespoons of the zucchini mixture at a time and use your hands to roll the mixture into balls. Arrange the zucchini balls on the pre­pared baking pan and bake for 25 minutes, or until firm and lightly browned.

FOR THE CHIMICHURRI SAUCE:
In a food proces­sor, combine all the chimichurri sauce ingredients plus ¼ cup of water and pulse to combine. Set aside.

FOR THE PASTA:
Cook the pasta according to package instructions in a pot of boiling water until al dente. Drain and return to the pot. Add the chi­michurri sauce and toss gently to combine. Divide the pasta into shallow serving bowls and top each portion with 2 or 3 zucchini meatballs.
Serves 4

The recipe is also here: https://bit.ly/3APEPqh

node.text:
In need of a healthy go-to snack that both kids and adults will enjoy? Check out these tasty Fruit and Nut Bars. Mix and match the dried fruit with what you have in your pantry. These store great in the fridge or the freezer. This recipe is from Steven, our Global Volunteer Director

INGREDIENTS
1 ½ cups of raw almonds
1 cup dates, pitted
1 cup of freeze dried blueberries or other unsweetened dried fruit (such as dried cherries)
1/2 cup of prunes

METHOD:
1. In a food processor, process the almonds until fine like flour. Adjust the almond flour so it does not stuck under the blade, make it loose.
2. Process the almond flour and the rest of the ingredients until mixed together well. It may be helpful to do this in small batches. 
3. Line a pan with parchment paper or use a glass baking dish, and add the mixture to the pan. Spread-out the mixture using the back of a spoon or clean hands, try to make it as even as possible. Place into the fridge to allow it to set. Once ready, slice the bars into desired sizes (10 large bars or about 30 bit-seized bars). Store remaining bars in the refrigerator or freezer.

Makes about 10 large bars or 30 bit-sized bars

node.text:
Researchers had people eat a bag of frozen kale and cabbage a day for just two weeks—which is great because you can just keep it in the freezer, pre-washed, pre-chopped, and just throw it in any meal you are making—and people had a significant reduction for total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and even blood sugar levels. And, the antioxidant capacity of their blood went up.⁠
 ⁠
Kale is a best-of-all-worlds food, low in calories and packed to the hilt with nutrition—vitamins, minerals, anti-inflammatory compounds, antioxidant phytonutrients—you name it.⁠
 ⁠
Watch the video "The Benefits of Kale & Cabbage for Cholesterol" to learn more: http://bit.ly/2y5TpOK⁠
⁠
* To access the link in this post, click the link in our bio and then select this image.⁠

node.text:
Here's an easy and delicious Daily Dozen inspired meal that uses some pantry staples. The recipe is from Kate, our Senior Director of Programs.

Ingredients:
3/4 cup uncooked quinoa
4 cups salt-free vegetable broth or water
1-2 Tablespoons salt-free southwest/chili seasoning (or to taste) 
1 large or 2 small sweet potatoes, diced
1.5 cups frozen corn kernels
1.5 cups cooked bean (any kind)
1 (BPA-free) can diced tomatoes or 1-2 fresh tomatoes, diced
Black pepper, to taste
Dried or fresh cilantro, to taste

Method:
Boil the quinoa in the broth and seasoning until it's almost cooked, covered (about 7 mins). Add the diced sweet potatoes and simmer until they are cooked, covered (about 10 mins). Add the tomatoes, corn, beans, black pepper and cilantro and cook until heated through. Adjust seasonings to taste. Optional: Add any kind of greens at a the end until wilted. Makes enough for about 4-6 people.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NutritionFacts.org on September 05, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says '"A single serving of four Brazil nuts improves cholesterol levels almost immediately." Michael Greger in How Not -NottoD to Die / NutritionFacts.org'.

node.text:
A single serving of Brazil nuts may lower cholesterol levels faster than statin drugs and keep them down even a month after eating them just once.⁠
⁠
Adding Brazil nuts may be a helpful strategy for lowering cholesterol, but we also need to consider overall dietary patterns. Plant-based diets have been shown to lower cholesterol just as effectively as first-line statin drugs, but without the risks.⁠
⁠
The best that cholesterol-lowering statin drugs appear to do is an absolute risk reduction of 3.1 percent over six years. If Dr. Esselstyn’s work can be replicated in a randomized controlled trial, then a whole food, plant-based diet will have been shown to work 20 times better with an absolute risk reduction of 60 percent after less than four years.⁠
⁠
To drastically reduce LDL cholesterol levels, it appears we need to drastically reduce our intake of trans fat, which comes from processed foods and naturally from meat and dairy, as well as saturated fat, which is found mainly in animal products and junk foods. Dietary cholesterol, which is found exclusively in animal-derived foods, especially eggs, plays a lesser role, but we should lower intake of that, too.⁠
⁠
In an upcoming series, I talk about the pros and cons of statin drug therapy. Spoiler: If you have a history of heart disease or stroke, taking a statin is recommended.⁠
⁠
Check out the following resources to learn more:⁠
"Four Nuts Once a Month" at https://bit.ly/3eBDxph⁠
⁠
"The Actual Benefit of Diet vs. Drugs" at http://bit.ly/2vD69WX⁠
⁠
Check out the cholesterol topic page at https://nutritionfacts.org/topics/cholesterol/.⁠
⁠
*To access the links, click the link in our bio and then select this image.⁠
